articles.headline: Online Music, Unshackled
articles.snippet: This month, via Spotify, the music world took a great step forward toward the holy grail of a free, legal, song-specific and convenient service.
articles.abstract: This month, via Spotify, the music world took a great step forward toward the holy grail of a free, legal, song-specific and convenient service.
articles.lead_paragraph: Everybody seems to think that record company executives are big, greedy dunderheads. “How dare you charge for music?” the college set shouts. “Music wants to be free!”

articles.headline: Study of Medical Device Rules Is Attacked, Unseen
articles.snippet: A report that could propose a tougher approval process prompted an extraordinary campaign by the industry.
articles.abstract: A report that could propose a tougher approval process prompted an extraordinary campaign by the industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Allies of the medical device industry are waging an extraordinary campaign in Washington to discredit a coming report by one of the country’s pre-eminent scientific groups that examines possible new regulations on the industry.

articles.headline: Congress at Impasse Over F.A.A.
articles.snippet: For four years and counting, Congress has been unable to approve long-term authority for the agency’s budgets.
articles.abstract: For four years and counting, Congress has been unable to approve long-term authority for the agency’s budgets.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The debt ceiling debate may seem to be taking forever, but as an example of legislative dysfunction it is difficult to beat the repeated failure of Congress to manage the affairs of the Federal Aviation Administration.

articles.headline: U.S. and Europe Battle Over Carbon Fees for Airlines
articles.snippet: By 2012, the price of a trans-Atlantic flight could be raised up to $57 to help pay for carbon permits.
articles.abstract: By 2012, the price of a trans-Atlantic flight could be raised up to $57 to help pay for carbon permits.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sharply divergent climate change policies on opposite sides of the Atlantic are setting off political fireworks as European environmental regulators prepare to extend their reach across the ocean. Starting Jan. 1, the European Union will require all carriers entering or leaving its airports to either reduce their emissions or pay a charge — whether the airline is United, Air France or Lufthansa.

articles.headline: With G.O.P. Unity at Risk, Boehner Tries Tougher Style
articles.snippet: With the nation’s economic standing and his own political future at risk, John A. Boehner, the speaker of the House, jettisoned his usual laissez-faire approach on Wednesday.
articles.abstract: With the nation’s economic standing and his own political future at risk, John A. Boehner, the speaker of the House, jettisoned his usual laissez-faire approach on Wednesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaker John A. Boehner is a laid-back leader who likes to say that his role is to let the House work its will. But with the nation’s economic standing and his own political future at risk, Mr. Boehner jettisoned his usual laissez-faire approach on Wednesday.

articles.headline: Investors, Worried About Debt Talks, Look for Havens
articles.snippet: Investors are seeking alternatives to United States Treasury bonds as worries escalate that lawmakers will fail to rein in the deficit and raise the federal debt limit in the coming days.
articles.abstract: Investors are seeking alternatives to United States Treasury bonds as worries escalate that lawmakers will fail to rein in the deficit and raise the federal debt limit in the coming days.
articles.lead_paragraph: Think of it as the flight to safety every investor would like a seat on. The only problem? Nothing is taking off.
articles.byline: By Eric Dash and Nelson D. Schwartz

articles.headline: Peach Rivalry Becomes War Between the Tastes
articles.snippet: While South Carolina has long produced more of the fruit, Georgians say victory comes down to a matter of taste.
articles.abstract: While South Carolina has long produced more of the fruit, Georgians say victory comes down to a matter of taste.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLEMSON, S.C. — The South has plenty of rivalries. Auburn and Alabama fight over football dominance. North Carolina and Tennessee battle over barbecue.

articles.headline: House Puts Off Debt Vote as Press by Boehner Fails
articles.snippet: G.O.P. leaders in the House abruptly put off a vote on the debt ceiling bill Thursday night, an indication that House Speaker John A. Boehner remained short of the votes necessary to pass his bill.
articles.abstract: G.O.P. leaders in the House abruptly put off a vote on the debt ceiling bill Thursday night, an indication that House Speaker John A. Boehner remained short of the votes necessary to pass his bill.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Short of support from their conservative members, House Republican leaders on Thursday abruptly put off a vote on their proposal to raise the debt ceiling and cut government spending, throwing last-ditch efforts to avert a government default next week into disarray.
